reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: Amazon sits well outside my circle. I’ve spent a lifetime understanding simple consumer products, railroads and insurance – not sprawling e-commerce, cloud computing and razor-thin retail margins. As I always say, “risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing.” I don’t fully grasp the long-term economics of AWS, logistics arbitrage and retail price wars. 2. Moat Assessment: While Amazon’s scale in e-commerce and cloud services seems formidable, the analysis shows inconsistent ROE (0/10 periods above 15%) and a shallow moat. Its operating margins are strong now, but fierce competition from Microsoft Azure, Walmart, Alibaba and others could erode that advantage. 3. Management Quality: Jeff Bezos is a visionary, but heavy reinvestment has produced negative owner earnings (-$10.9 billion). There’s little sign of discipline in returning capital to shareholders, and stock issuance and minimal dividends offer no comfort. 4. Financial Health & Consistency: Weak ROE (5.9%), high debt/equity (1.3), negative owner earnings and lumpy earnings growth reveal a financial fortress with holes. Inconsistent results make it hard to predict long-term profits. 5. Valuation: A three-stage DCF spits out a negative intrinsic value and a margin of safety of –109%. By every reasonable measure, shares trade well above any rational value estimate. 6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: E-commerce and cloud will grow, but margins, capital intensity and competition remain wild cards. Rapid change in technology and customer behavior adds risk. 7. Portfolio Comparison: I’d much rather own Coca-Cola, Apple or BNSF at fair prices – wonderful businesses with durable moats, honest managers and sensible valuations. In contrast, Amazon is complex, losing money on owner-earnings basis and wildly overvalued. When in doubt, the answer is “no.” This is an emphatic “no.”

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 5.9%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.3; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 855.8% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 55.3%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (8.0%, 5y), Stage 2 (4.0%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
